text: Who is the author of the Book of Romans?
verseText: Paul, a servant of Christ Jesus, called to be an apostle, set apart for the gospel of God,

text: What is the central theme of Romans?
options: The gospel of God's righteousness revealed through faith in Jesus Christ
verseText: For I am not ashamed of the gospel, for it is the power of God for salvation to everyone who believes, to the Jew first and also to the Greek. For in it the righteousness of God is revealed from faith for faith, as it is written, “The righteous shall live by faith.”

text: According to Romans 3:23, who has sinned and fallen short of the glory of God?
verseText: for all have sinned and fall short of the glory of God,

text: Romans 5:1 states that since we have been justified by faith, we have what with God?
verseText: Therefore, since we have been justified by faith, we have peace with God through our Lord Jesus Christ.

text: What concept does Paul explain in Romans 6, emphasizing freedom from sin's dominion?
options: Baptism into Christ's death and resurrection
verseText: Do you not know that all of us who have been baptized into Christ Jesus were baptized into his death? We were buried therefore with him by baptism into death, in order that, just as Christ was raised from the dead by the glory of the Father, we too might walk in newness of life... So you also must consider yourselves dead to sin and alive to God in Christ Jesus.

text: Romans 8:1 declares that there is now no what for those who are in Christ Jesus?
verseText: There is therefore now no condemnation for those who are in Christ Jesus.

text: What famous passage in Romans 8 assures believers that nothing can separate them from God's love?
verseText: For I am sure that neither death nor life, nor angels nor rulers, nor things present nor things to come, nor powers, nor height nor depth, nor anything else in all creation, will be able to separate us from the love of God in Christ Jesus our Lord.

text: In Romans 9-11, Paul discusses the complex relationship between God's plan and whom?
verseText: (These chapters explore God's sovereignty, Israel's unbelief, the inclusion of Gentiles, and God's ultimate saving purposes for Israel).

text: Romans 12:1 urges believers to present their bodies as what?
options: A living sacrifice, holy and acceptable to God
verseText: I appeal to you therefore, brothers, by the mercies of God, to present your bodies as a living sacrifice, holy and acceptable to God, which is your spiritual worship.

text: How does Paul instruct believers in Rome to relate to governing authorities (Romans 13)?
options: Be subject to them, for they are instituted by God
verseText: Let every person be subject to the governing authorities. For there is no authority except from God, and those that exist have been instituted by God.

text: In the opening chapter, Paul argues that God's invisible attributes, eternal power, and divine nature are clearly perceived through what?
verseText: For his invisible attributes, namely, his eternal power and divine nature, have been clearly perceived, ever since the creation of the world, in the things that have been made. So they are without excuse.

text: Paul contends that Gentile unrighteousness is demonstrated by their suppression of the truth and exchange of God's glory for what?
verseText: For although they knew God, they did not honor him as God or give thanks to him, but they became futile in their thinking, and their foolish hearts were darkened... and exchanged the glory of the immortal God for images resembling mortal man and birds and animals and creeping things.

text: In Romans 2, Paul addresses the Jews, arguing that possessing the Law and circumcision does not exempt them from judgment if they do what?
options: Fail to keep the Law themselves
verseText: But if you call yourself a Jew and rely on the law and boast in God... you who preach against stealing, do you steal? You who say that one must not commit adultery, do you commit adultery? You who abhor idols, do you rob temples?

text: What defines a 'true Jew' according to Paul's argument in Romans 2?
options: One who is a Jew inwardly, with circumcision of the heart by the Spirit
verseText: For no one is a Jew who is merely one outwardly, nor is circumcision outward and physical. But a Jew is one inwardly, and circumcision is a matter of the heart, by the Spirit, not by the letter. His praise is not from man but from God.

text: Paul quotes the Old Testament extensively in Romans 3 to demonstrate what universal truth before concluding 'all have sinned'?
options: That no one is righteous, not even one
verseText: as it is written: “None is righteous, no, not one; no one understands; no one seeks for God. All have turned aside; together they have become worthless; no one does good, not even one.”

text: What function did the Law serve, according to Paul in Romans 3, if not justification?
verseText: For by works of the law no human being will be justified in his sight, since through the law comes knowledge of sin.

text: How is God's righteousness revealed apart from the Law, as explained in Romans 3?
options: Through faith in Jesus Christ for all who believe
verseText: But now the righteousness of God has been manifested apart from the law, although the Law and the Prophets bear witness to it— the righteousness of God through faith in Jesus Christ for all who believe.

text: What term does Paul use in Romans 3 to describe Christ's sacrifice as an appeasement of God's wrath against sin?
verseText: whom God put forward as a propitiation by his blood, to be received by faith. This was to show God's righteousness, because in his divine forbearance he had passed over former sins.

text: Paul uses which Old Testament figure in Romans 4 as the primary example of justification by faith?
verseText: For what does the Scripture say? “Abraham believed God, and it was counted to him as righteousness.”

text: Abraham's faith was counted as righteousness before or after he was circumcised?
verseText: How then was it counted to him? Was it before or after he had been circumcised? It was not after, but before he was circumcised. He received the sign of circumcision as a seal of the righteousness that he had by faith while he was still uncircumcised.

text: Besides Abraham, which other Old Testament figure does Paul quote in Romans 4 regarding the blessing of having sins forgiven and covered?
verseText: just as David also speaks of the blessing of the one to whom God counts righteousness apart from works: “Blessed are those whose lawless deeds are forgiven, and whose sins are covered; blessed is the man against whom the Lord will not count his sin.”

text: Romans 5 contrasts the results of Adam's trespass with the results of Christ's one act of righteousness. What came through Adam, and what came through Christ?
options: Life through Adam, death through Christ
Condemnation/death through Adam, justification/life through Christ
Law through Adam, grace through Christ
Ignorance through Adam, knowledge through Christ
verseText: Therefore, as one trespass led to condemnation for all men, so one act of righteousness leads to justification and life for all men.

text: What does Paul say 'abounded all the more' where sin increased?
verseText: Now the law came in to increase the trespass, but where sin increased, grace abounded all the more,

text: What rhetorical question does Paul strongly refute at the beginning of Romans 6, following his statement about grace abounding?
options: 'Should we keep sinning so that grace may increase?'
verseText: What shall we say then? Are we to continue in sin that grace may abound? By no means! How can we who died to sin still live in it?

text: Believers are urged in Romans 6 not to let sin reign in their mortal bodies but to present themselves to God as instruments of what?
verseText: Do not present your members to sin as instruments for unrighteousness, but present yourselves to God as those who have been brought from death to life, and your members to God as instruments for righteousness.

text: What are the 'wages' of sin, according to Romans 6?
verseText: For the wages of sin is death, but the free gift of God is eternal life in Christ Jesus our Lord.

text: What is contrasted with the wages of sin in Romans 6:23?
options: The free gift of God, which is eternal life
verseText: For the wages of sin is death, but the free gift of God is eternal life in Christ Jesus our Lord.

text: In Romans 7, Paul uses the analogy of marriage to illustrate what point about the Law?
options: Believers are released from the Law through the death of Christ, free to belong to Him
verseText: Likewise, my brothers, you also have died to the law through the body of Christ, so that you may belong to another, to him who has been raised from the dead, in order that we may bear fruit for God.

text: Paul describes an internal struggle in Romans 7 between his desire to do good and the sin dwelling within him. What does he exclaim in despair?
options: 'What must I do to be saved?'
'Wretched man that I am! Who will deliver me from this body of death?'
verseText: Wretched man that I am! Who will deliver me from this body of death?

text: Who provides the deliverance from the 'body of death' mentioned in Romans 7?
options: God through Jesus Christ our Lord
verseText: Thanks be to God through Jesus Christ our Lord! So then, I myself serve the law of God with my mind, but with my flesh I serve the law of sin.

text: What indwelling power enables believers to fulfill the righteous requirement of the Law, according to Romans 8?
verseText: in order that the righteous requirement of the law might be fulfilled in us, who walk not according to the flesh but according to the Spirit.

text: Those who live according to the flesh set their minds on the things of the flesh, while those who live according to the Spirit set their minds on what?
verseText: For those who live according to the flesh set their minds on the things of the flesh, but those who live according to the Spirit set their minds on the things of the Spirit.

text: What relationship with God do believers receive through the Spirit, replacing a spirit of fear?
verseText: For you did not receive the spirit of slavery to fall back into fear, but you have received the Spirit of adoption as sons, by whom we cry, “Abba! Father!”

text: The Spirit helps believers in their weakness by doing what for them?
options: Interceding for them with groanings too deep for words
verseText: Likewise the Spirit helps us in our weakness. For we do not know what to pray for as we ought, but the Spirit himself intercedes for us with groanings too deep for words.

text: What promise is given in Romans 8:28 regarding God's working in the lives of those who love Him?
options: All things work together for good
verseText: And we know that for those who love God all things work together for good, for those who are called according to his purpose.

text: Paul outlines a sequence of God's saving actions in Romans 8: foreknown, predestined, called, justified, and what final step?
verseText: And those whom he predestined he also called, and those whom he called he also justified, and those whom he justified he also glorified.

text: If God is for us, what rhetorical question does Paul ask in Romans 8?
verseText: What then shall we say to these things? If God is for us, who can be against us?

text: Who does Paul say brings a charge against God's elect, and who condemns them, in Romans 8?
options: No one (God justifies) / No one (Christ intercedes)
Their own conscience / Their past sins
verseText: Who shall bring any charge against God's elect? It is God who justifies. Who is to condemn? Christ Jesus is the one who died—more than that, who was raised—who is at the right hand of God, who indeed is interceding for us.

text: Paul expresses great sorrow and anguish in Romans 9 over what?
options: The unbelief of his kinsmen according to the flesh (Israel)
verseText: I am speaking the truth in Christ—I am not lying; my conscience bears me witness in the Holy Spirit— that I have great sorrow and unceasing anguish in my heart. For I could wish that I myself were accursed and cut off from Christ for the sake of my brothers, my kinsmen according to the flesh.

text: Paul uses the Old Testament examples of Jacob and Esau in Romans 9 to illustrate what principle about God's choice?
options: It is based on human merit
It is based on foreseen faith
It depends not on human will or exertion, but on God's mercy (sovereign choice)
verseText: though they were not yet born and had done nothing either good or bad—in order that God's purpose of election might continue, not because of works but because of him who calls— she was told, “The older will serve the younger.”... So then it depends not on human will or exertion, but on God who has mercy.

text: What analogy does Paul use in Romans 9 to counter objections about God's fairness in choosing some and hardening others?
verseText: But who are you, O man, to answer back to God? Will what is molded say to its molder, “Why have you made me like this?” Has the potter no right over the clay, to make out of the same lump one vessel for honorable use and another for dishonorable use?

text: In Romans 10, Paul states that Israel's zeal for God was not based on what?
verseText: For I bear them witness that they have a zeal for God, but not according to knowledge.

text: How does Paul describe the righteousness that comes from faith in Romans 10, contrasting it with righteousness from the Law?
options: It is far away and hard to find
The word is near you, in your mouth and heart (the word of faith)
It is only for the Jews
verseText: But the righteousness based on faith says, “Do not say in your heart, ‘Who will ascend into heaven?’” (that is, to bring Christ down) “or ‘Who will descend into the abyss?’” (that is, to bring Christ up from the dead). But what does it say? “The word is near you, in your mouth and in your heart” (that is, the word of faith that we proclaim);

text: What confession and belief leads to salvation, according to Romans 10?
options: Confessing the Law and believing Moses
Confessing Caesar is Lord and believing in Rome
Confessing Jesus is Lord and believing God raised him from the dead
Confessing one's sins and believing in self-improvement
verseText: because, if you confess with your mouth that Jesus is Lord and believe in your heart that God raised him from the dead, you will be saved.

text: For people to call on the Lord and be saved, what sequence of events must happen first, according to Romans 10?
options: They must see miracles, then believe
They must feel remorse, then confess
They must believe, which requires hearing, which requires a preacher being sent
They must read the Law, then understand
verseText: How then will they call on him in whom they have not believed? And how are they to believe in him of whom they have never heard? And how are they to hear without someone preaching? And how are they to preach unless they are sent?

text: Paul asks in Romans 11 if God has rejected His people (Israel). What is his emphatic answer?
verseText: I ask, then, has God rejected his people? By no means! For I myself am an Israelite, a descendant of Abraham, a member of the tribe of Benjamin.

text: Paul speaks of a 'remnant' of Israel chosen by what?
verseText: So too at the present time there is a remnant, chosen by grace.

text: What analogy does Paul use in Romans 11 to illustrate the relationship between Israel and Gentile believers?
options: An olive tree with natural branches (Israel) and wild branches grafted in (Gentiles)
A vineyard with different types of grapes
verseText: But if some of the branches were broken off, and you, although a wild olive shoot, were grafted in among the others and now share in the nourishing root of the olive tree...

text: What warning does Paul give the Gentile believers in the olive tree analogy?
options: To separate from the Jewish believers
Not to become arrogant, but to stand fast through faith
verseText: That is true. They were broken off because of their unbelief, but you stand fast through faith. So do not become proud, but fear. For if God did not spare the natural branches, neither will he spare you.

text: Paul reveals a 'mystery' in Romans 11 concerning Israel's hardening and the inclusion of Gentiles. How long will the partial hardening of Israel last?
options: Until the fullness of the Gentiles has come in
verseText: Lest you be wise in your own sight, I do not want you to be unaware of this mystery, brothers: a partial hardening has come upon Israel, until the fullness of the Gentiles has come in.

text: What is the ultimate outcome for 'all Israel' according to Romans 11?
options: They will be permanently cut off
They will merge with the Gentiles
verseText: And in this way all Israel will be saved, as it is written, “The Deliverer will come from Zion, he will banish ungodliness from Jacob”;

text: How does Paul conclude his discussion of God's plan for Israel and Gentiles in Romans 11, before transitioning to practical application?
options: With a doxology praising God's unfathomable wisdom and ways
verseText: Oh, the depth of the riches and wisdom and knowledge of God! How unsearchable are his judgments and how inscrutable his ways! ... For from him and through him and to him are all things. To him be glory forever. Amen.

text: Presenting our bodies as a living sacrifice is described as our 'spiritual worship' or 'reasonable service'. What else are believers urged NOT to do in Romans 12?
verseText: Do not be conformed to this world, but be transformed by the renewal of your mind, that by testing you may discern what is the will of God, what is good and acceptable and perfect.

text: How should believers be transformed, according to Romans 12?
options: By the renewal of their minds
verseText: Do not be conformed to this world, but be transformed by the renewal of your mind, that by testing you may discern what is the will of God, what is good and acceptable and perfect.

text: Paul instructs believers in Romans 12 not to think of themselves more highly than they ought, but to think with what?
verseText: For by the grace given to me I say to everyone among you not to think of himself more highly than he ought to think, but to think with sober judgment, each according to the measure of faith that God has assigned.

text: The analogy of the body with many members having different functions is used in Romans 12 to illustrate what aspect of the church?
options: The diversity of spiritual gifts and unity in Christ
verseText: For as in one body we have many members, and the members do not all have the same function, so we, though many, are one body in Christ, and individually members one of another. Having gifts that differ according to the grace given to us, let us use them:

text: What characteristics should mark a believer's love, according to Romans 12?
options: Genuineness (abhorring evil, holding fast to good)
verseText: Let love be genuine. Abhor what is evil; hold fast to what is good.

text: How should believers treat those who persecute them, according to Romans 12?
options: Bless them and do not curse them
verseText: Bless those who persecute you; bless and do not curse them.

text: Instead of taking revenge, what are believers instructed to do in Romans 12?
options: Leave it to the wrath of God
verseText: Beloved, never avenge yourselves, but leave it to the wrath of God, for it is written, “Vengeance is mine, I will repay, says the Lord.”

text: How can believers 'overcome evil', according to the end of Romans 12?
verseText: Do not be overcome by evil, but overcome evil with good.

text: What specific obligation does Paul mention believers should fulfill towards governing authorities in Romans 13?
verseText: For because of this you also pay taxes, for the authorities are ministers of God, attending to this very thing. Pay to all what is owed to them: taxes to whom taxes are owed, revenue to whom revenue is owed, respect to whom respect is owed, honor to whom honor is owed.

text: Besides submitting to authorities, what overarching command fulfills the Law's requirements regarding neighbors, according to Romans 13?
verseText: Owe no one anything, except to love each other, for the one who loves another has fulfilled the law... And any other commandment, are summed up in this word: “You shall love your neighbor as yourself.”

text: Paul urges believers in Romans 13 to 'wake from sleep' because what is nearer than when they first believed?
verseText: Besides this you know the time, that the hour has come for you to wake from sleep. For salvation is nearer to us now than when we first believed.

text: Instead of making provision for the flesh, what are believers instructed to 'put on' in Romans 13?
verseText: But put on the Lord Jesus Christ, and make no provision for the flesh, to gratify its desires.

text: Romans 14 deals with disputes over 'doubtful matters'. What examples does Paul use?
options: Eating certain foods (like meat vs. vegetables) and observing special days
verseText: One person believes he may eat anything, while the weak person eats only vegetables... One person esteems one day as better than another, while another esteems all days alike.

text: What principle should guide believers ('the strong') in their interactions with those who have scruples about doubtful matters ('the weak')?
options: Welcome them without quarreling and avoid causing them to stumble
verseText: As for the one who is weak in faith, welcome him, but not to quarrel over opinions... Therefore let us not pass judgment on one another any longer, but rather decide never to put a stumbling block or hindrance in the way of a brother.

text: The Kingdom of God is not a matter of eating and drinking, but of what, according to Romans 14?
options: Righteousness and peace and joy in the Holy Spirit
verseText: For the kingdom of God is not a matter of eating and drinking but of righteousness and peace and joy in the Holy Spirit.

text: What should be the aim of believers in their interactions, according to Romans 14:19?
options: Pursuing what makes for peace and mutual upbuilding
verseText: So then let us pursue what makes for peace and for mutual upbuilding.

text: Romans 15 begins by stating that the strong ought to bear with the failings of the weak and not do what?
verseText: We who are strong have an obligation to bear with the failings of the weak, and not to please ourselves.

text: Paul quotes the Old Testament in Romans 15 to show that Christ became a servant to the circumcised (Jews) to confirm God's promises and also so that who might glorify God?
verseText: For I tell you that Christ became a servant to the circumcised to show God's truthfulness, in order to confirm the promises given to the patriarchs, and in order that the Gentiles might glorify God for his mercy.

text: What was Paul's ambition in his missionary work, as stated in Romans 15?
options: To preach only where churches already existed
To preach the gospel where Christ had not been named
To focus only on major cities
To write as many letters as possible
verseText: and thus I make it my ambition to preach the gospel, not where Christ has already been named, lest I build on someone else's foundation,

text: Paul expresses his hope to visit Rome on his way to what further destination?
verseText: I hope to see you in passing as I go to Spain, and to be helped on my journey there by you... I shall go on by way of you to Spain.

text: Before visiting Rome, Paul was heading to Jerusalem for what purpose?
options: To be tried by the Sanhedrin
To deliver a contribution from the Gentile churches for the poor saints there
verseText: At present, however, I am going to Jerusalem bringing aid to the saints. For Macedonia and Achaia have been pleased to make some contribution for the poor among the saints at Jerusalem.

text: Paul asks the Roman believers to strive together with him in prayers for what specific requests regarding his Jerusalem trip?
options: That he might be delivered from unbelievers in Judea and his service be acceptable to the saints
verseText: I appeal to you, brothers, by our Lord Jesus Christ and by the love of the Spirit, to strive together with me in your prayers to God on my behalf, that I may be delivered from the unbelievers in Judea, and that my service for Jerusalem may be acceptable to the saints,

text: In Romans 16, Paul commends whom to the Roman church, describing her as a servant (or deaconess) of the church in Cenchreae?
verseText: I commend to you our sister Phoebe, a servant of the church at Cenchreae, that you may welcome her in the Lord in a way worthy of the saints, and help her in whatever she may need from you, for she has been a patron of many and of myself as well.

text: Which couple does Paul greet warmly in Romans 16, calling them fellow workers who risked their necks for his life?
verseText: Greet Prisca [Priscilla] and Aquila, my fellow workers in Christ Jesus, who risked their necks for my life, to whom not only I give thanks but all the churches of the Gentiles give thanks as well.

text: Paul warns the Romans in chapter 16 to watch out for those who cause what?
options: Divisions and obstacles contrary to the doctrine they had learned
verseText: I appeal to you, brothers, to watch out for those who cause divisions and create obstacles contrary to the doctrine that you have been taught; avoid them.

text: Who served as Paul's amanuensis (scribe) in writing the letter to the Romans?
verseText: I Tertius, who wrote this letter, greet you in the Lord.

text: The final verses of Romans (16:25-27) form a doxology praising God for His power to establish believers according to Paul's gospel and the revelation of what?
options: The mystery hidden for long ages but now disclosed
verseText: Now to him who is able to strengthen you according to my gospel and the preaching of Jesus Christ, according to the revelation of the mystery that was kept secret for long ages but has now been disclosed and through the prophetic writings has been made known to all nations...

text: Paul describes himself in the opening as 'set apart' for what?
verseText: Paul, a servant of Christ Jesus, called to be an apostle, set apart for the gospel of God,

text: The gospel Paul preaches concerns God's Son, who was descended from whom according to the flesh?
verseText: concerning his Son, who was descended from David according to the flesh

text: How was Jesus declared to be the Son of God in power, according to Romans 1?
options: By His resurrection from the dead
verseText: and was declared to be the Son of God in power according to the Spirit of holiness by his resurrection from the dead, Jesus Christ our Lord,

text: Paul expresses his eagerness to preach the gospel also to those where?
verseText: So I am eager to preach the gospel to you also who are in Rome.

text: The righteousness of God is revealed in the gospel 'from faith for faith'. What Old Testament quote supports this?
options: 'The just shall live by his faith'
'The fear of the Lord is the beginning of wisdom'
verseText: For in it the righteousness of God is revealed from faith for faith, as it is written, “The righteous shall live by faith.”

text: God's wrath is revealed against ungodliness and unrighteousness of men who do what with the truth?
verseText: For the wrath of God is revealed from heaven against all ungodliness and unrighteousness of men, who by their unrighteousness suppress the truth.

text: Because humans exchanged the truth about God for a lie and worshiped creation, God gave them up to what?
options: Dishonorable passions and a debased mind
verseText: Therefore God gave them up in the lusts of their hearts to impurity... For this reason God gave them up to dishonorable passions... And since they did not see fit to acknowledge God, God gave them up to a debased mind to do what ought not to be done.

text: In Romans 2, Paul argues that those who judge others condemn themselves. Why?
options: Because they practice the very same things
verseText: Therefore you have no excuse, O man, every one of you who judges. For in passing judgment on another you condemn yourself, because you, the judge, practice the very same things.

text: God's kindness, forbearance, and patience are meant to lead people toward what?
verseText: Or do you presume on the riches of his kindness and forbearance and patience, not knowing that God's kindness is meant to lead you to repentance?

text: God will render to each one according to what, according to Romans 2?
verseText: He will render to each one according to his works:

text: Paul states that it is not the hearers of the Law but the ______ of the Law who will be justified.
verseText: For it is not the hearers of the law who are righteous before God, but the doers of the law who will be justified.

text: What advantage did the Jew have, or what was the value of circumcision, according to Paul's initial question in Romans 3?
options: Mainly that they were entrusted with the oracles of God
verseText: Then what advantage has the Jew? Or what is the value of circumcision? Much in every way. To begin with, the Jews were entrusted with the oracles of God.

text: Does the unfaithfulness of some nullify the faithfulness of God?
verseText: What if some were unfaithful? Does their faithlessness nullify the faithfulness of God? By no means! Let God be true though every one were a liar,

text: Justification through faith demonstrates God's righteousness because He is both just and the ______ of the one who has faith in Jesus.
verseText: it was to show his righteousness at the present time, so that he might be just and the justifier of the one who has faith in Jesus.

text: If justification is by faith, what happens to boasting?
options: It shifts to boasting in the Law
verseText: Then what becomes of our boasting? It is excluded. By what kind of law? By a law of works? No, but by the law of faith.

text: Does faith overthrow the Law, according to Paul's conclusion in Romans 3?
options: No, on the contrary, it upholds the Law
It replaces the Law with grace
verseText: Do we then overthrow the law by this faith? By no means! On the contrary, we uphold the law.

text: Abraham was declared righteous by faith while he was still what?
verseText: It was not after, but before he was circumcised. He received the sign of circumcision as a seal of the righteousness that he had by faith while he was still uncircumcised.

text: The promise to Abraham and his offspring depended on the righteousness of faith so that it might be guaranteed to all offspring based on what?
verseText: That is why it depends on faith, in order that the promise may rest on grace and be guaranteed to all his offspring—not only to the adherent of the law but also to the one who shares the faith of Abraham, who is the father of us all,

text: Abraham's faith was strong despite facing the 'deadness' of his own body and what else?
verseText: He did not weaken in faith when he considered his own body, which was as good as dead (since he was about a hundred years old), or when he considered the barrenness [deadness] of Sarah's womb.

text: Besides peace with God, what else have believers gained access to through faith, according to Romans 5?
options: This grace in which we stand
verseText: Through him we have also obtained access by faith into this grace in which we stand, and we rejoice in hope of the glory of God.

text: Paul says believers rejoice in sufferings, knowing that suffering produces what?
verseText: Not only that, but we rejoice in our sufferings, knowing that suffering produces endurance,

text: Endurance produces character, and character produces what?
verseText: and endurance produces character, and character produces hope,

text: Why does this hope not put us to shame?
options: Because God's love has been poured into our hearts through the Holy Spirit
verseText: and hope does not put us to shame, because God's love has been poured into our hearts through the Holy Spirit who has been given to us.

text: Christ died for the ungodly at what time?
verseText: For while we were still weak, at the right time Christ died for the ungodly... but God shows his love for us in that while we were still sinners, Christ died for us.

text: If believers were reconciled to God through Christ's death while enemies, what are they assured of now?
verseText: For if while we were enemies we were reconciled to God by the death of his Son, much more, now that we are reconciled, shall we be saved by his life.

text: Through whom did sin and death enter the world?
verseText: Therefore, just as sin came into the world through one man, and death through sin, and so death spread to all men because all sinned—

text: Why did the Law come in, according to Romans 5?
verseText: Now the law came in to increase the trespass, but where sin increased, grace abounded all the more,

text: Being united with Christ in His death through baptism means believers should also walk in what?
verseText: We were buried therefore with him by baptism into death, in order that, just as Christ was raised from the dead by the glory of the Father, we too might walk in newness of life.

text: What does Paul mean when he says believers are 'dead to sin'?
options: Sin has no more power or claim over them
verseText: So you also must consider yourselves dead to sin and alive to God in Christ Jesus.

text: Having been set free from sin, believers have become slaves to what?
verseText: and, having been set free from sin, have become slaves of righteousness... But now that you have been set free from sin and have become slaves of God...

text: The result (fruit) of being enslaved to God is sanctification, and its end is what?
verseText: But now that you have been set free from sin and have become slaves of God, the fruit you get leads to sanctification and its end, eternal life.

text: Paul clarifies in Romans 7 that the Law itself is not sin, but rather it did what?
verseText: What then shall we say? That the law is sin? By no means! Yet if it had not been for the law, I would not have known sin. For I would not have known what it is to covet if the law had not said, “You shall not covet.”

text: Paul describes the Law as holy, righteous, and what else?
verseText: So the law is holy, and the commandment is holy and righteous and good.

text: What prevents Paul from doing the good he wants to do in the struggle described in Romans 7?
verseText: So now it is no longer I who do it, but sin that dwells within me... Now if I do what I do not want, it is no longer I who do it, but sin that dwells within me.

text: The 'law of sin and death' is contrasted in Romans 8 with what other law?
options: The law of the Spirit of life
verseText: For the law of the Spirit of life has set you free in Christ Jesus from the law of sin and death.

text: What could the Law not do because it was weakened by the flesh, which God did by sending His Son?
verseText: For God has done what the law, weakened by the flesh, could not do. By sending his own Son in the likeness of sinful flesh and for sin, he condemned sin in the flesh,

text: To set the mind on the flesh is death, but to set the mind on the Spirit is what?
verseText: For to set the mind on the flesh is death, but to set the mind on the Spirit is life and peace.

text: If the Spirit of God dwells in someone, they are not in the flesh but in the Spirit. What is true if someone does NOT have the Spirit of Christ?
options: They do not belong to Him
verseText: You, however, are not in the flesh but in the Spirit, if in fact the Spirit of God dwells in you. Anyone who does not have the Spirit of Christ does not belong to him.

text: Believers are debtors, but not to whom?
verseText: So then, brothers, we are debtors, not to the flesh, to live according to the flesh.

text: All who are led by the Spirit of God are what?
verseText: For all who are led by the Spirit of God are sons of God.

text: The Spirit Himself bears witness with our spirit that we are what?
verseText: The Spirit himself bears witness with our spirit that we are children of God,

text: If we are children of God, then we are heirs - heirs of God and fellow heirs with whom?
verseText: and if children, then heirs—heirs of God and fellow heirs with Christ, provided we suffer with him in order that we may also be glorified with him.

text: Paul considers that present sufferings are not worth comparing to what?
options: The glory that is to be revealed to us
verseText: For I consider that the sufferings of this present time are not worth comparing with the glory that is to be revealed to us.

text: What does the creation await with eager longing?
options: The revealing of the sons of God
verseText: For the creation waits with eager longing for the revealing of the sons of God.

text: Creation was subjected to futility, but in hope that it will be set free from what?
verseText: For the creation was subjected to futility, not willingly, but because of him who subjected it, in hope that the creation itself will be set free from its bondage to corruption and obtain the freedom of the glory of the children of God.

text: Not only creation, but believers who have the firstfruits of the Spirit also do what inwardly?
options: Groan inwardly, awaiting adoption and redemption
verseText: And not only the creation, but we ourselves, who have the firstfruits of the Spirit, groan inwardly as we wait eagerly for adoption as sons, the redemption of our bodies.

text: In hope we were saved. But hope that is seen is not hope. What does Paul say we do if we hope for what we do not see?
options: We wait for it with patience
verseText: For in this hope we were saved. Now hope that is seen is not hope. For who hopes for what he sees? But if we hope for what we do not see, we wait for it with patience.

text: Who intercedes for the saints according to the will of God?
verseText: And he who searches hearts knows what is the mind of the Spirit, because the Spirit intercedes for the saints according to the will of God.

text: Those whom God foreknew, He also predestined to be conformed to what?
verseText: For those whom he foreknew he also predestined to be conformed to the image of his Son, in order that he might be the firstborn among many brothers.

text: God did not spare His own Son but gave Him up for us all. What else will He give us along with Him?
verseText: He who did not spare his own Son but gave him up for us all, how will he not also with him graciously give us all things?

text: Who is at the right hand of God, interceding for believers?
verseText: Who is to condemn? Christ Jesus is the one who died—more than that, who was raised—who is at the right hand of God, who indeed is interceding for us.

text: In all the trials listed (tribulation, distress, persecution, etc.), what is the status of believers through Him who loved them?
verseText: No, in all these things we are more than conquerors through him who loved us.

text: Paul lists several privileges belonging to the Israelites in Romans 9. Which of these is NOT listed?
options: The adoption, the glory, the covenants
The giving of the law, the worship, the promises
The patriarchs, and Christ according to the flesh
verseText: They are Israelites, and to them belong the adoption, the glory, the covenants, the giving of the law, the worship, and the promises. To them belong the patriarchs, and from their race, according to the flesh, is the Christ, who is God over all, blessed forever. Amen.

text: Not all who are descended from Israel belong to Israel. This illustrates that God's promise is realized through which children?
options: Children who keep the Law perfectly
verseText: But it is not as though the word of God has failed. For not all who are descended from Israel belong to Israel, and not all are children of Abraham because they are his offspring... This means that it is not the children of the flesh who are the children of God, but the children of the promise are counted as offspring.

text: Paul quotes God's words to Moses: 'I will have mercy on whom I have mercy, and I will have _______ on whom I have _______.'
verseText: For he says to Moses, “I will have mercy on whom I have mercy, and I will have compassion on whom I have compassion.”

text: God endured vessels of wrath prepared for destruction in order to make known what?
options: The riches of His glory for vessels of mercy
verseText: What if God, desiring to show his wrath and to make known his power, has endured with much patience vessels of wrath prepared for destruction, in order to make known the riches of his glory for vessels of mercy, which he has prepared beforehand for glory—

text: Israel pursued righteousness based on the Law but failed to attain it because they pursued it by works instead of by what?
verseText: but that Israel who pursued a law that would lead to righteousness did not succeed in reaching that law. Why? Because they did not pursue it by faith, but as if it were based on works.

text: Christ is the end of the Law for what purpose, for everyone who believes?
verseText: For Christ is the end of the law for righteousness to everyone who believes.

text: With what does one believe, resulting in righteousness, according to Romans 10?
verseText: For with the heart one believes and is justified [lit: results in righteousness], and with the mouth one confesses and is saved.

text: With what does one confess, resulting in salvation, according to Romans 10?
verseText: For with the heart one believes and is justified, and with the mouth one confesses and is saved.

text: Is there a distinction between Jew and Greek regarding calling on the Lord for salvation?
options: No, the same Lord is Lord of all, bestowing riches on all who call
verseText: For there is no distinction between Jew and Greek; for the same Lord is Lord of all, bestowing his riches on all who call on him. For “everyone who calls on the name of the Lord will be saved.”

text: How beautiful are the feet of those who preach what?
verseText: And how are they to preach unless they are sent? As it is written, “How beautiful are the feet of those who preach the good news!”

text: Faith comes from hearing, and hearing comes through what?
verseText: So faith comes from hearing, and hearing through the word of Christ.

text: Paul uses the example of Elijah to show that God has always preserved what?
verseText: Do you not know what the Scripture says of Elijah, how he appeals to God against Israel? ... But what is God's reply to him? “I have kept for myself seven thousand men who have not bowed the knee to Baal.” So too at the present time there is a remnant, chosen by grace.

text: If salvation is by grace, it is no longer on the basis of what?
verseText: But if it is by grace, it is no longer on the basis of works; otherwise grace would no longer be grace.
